site_name: 113 Tolworth Rise NorthAnd Land To Rear Of No.s 107,109 And 113TolworthSurbitonKT5 9EP

constraints_details.constraints_layer_description: KEYACH Name: Tolworth Key Area of Change
AIRCZ Type:: Gatwick Airport Wind Turbine Consultation Zone:Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Gatwick Airport Limited, 7th Floor Destinations Place, London Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH06 0NP

description: Part demolition of no. 113 Tolworth Rise North to allow for new road to provide access for 8no. proposed new houses comprising 7no. 3 storey, three-bedroom houses and 1no. 3 storey, four-bedroom house with associated landscaping, amenity space, parking (with electric charging points) and refuse/recycling facilities (following demolition of existing turkey sheds)
decision_conditions: The proposed development, by reason of the floor-to-ceiling heights of the proposed dwellings, would provide substandard internal accommodation, resulting in unacceptable living conditions for future occupants of the development. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy D6 of the London Plan 2021.

The proposed development, by reason of its scale, form, siting and design, would appear as an unduly cramped and incongruous form of backland development, resulting in unacceptable harm to the character and appearance of the area. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The proposed development, by reason of the siting of car parking spaces within close proximity to the flank wall of 111 Tolworth Rise North, would result in unacceptable living conditions for the occupants of this property by way of noise, vibration and light spillage. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The proposed development would provide an excessive number of car parking spaces and in doing so would fail to adequately promote sustainable modes of transport and would result in a development dominated by cars. The proposal is therefore contrary to policies T6 and T6.1 of the London Plan 2021 and policies DM9 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The applicant has failed to demonstrate that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on protected species or ensure a biodiversity net gain. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy G6 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM6 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.
The submitted site plan and block plan is not labelled as existing or proposed, please amend the site plan and block plan with correct labelling existing or proposed.
Please provide 'Biodiversity Checklist.' The Biodiversity Checklists can be obtained via the council's website:https://www.kingston.gov.uk/downloads/file/2738/biodiversity-checklist
Please provide 'Time Stamp Photo'. It is validation requirement.
Please submit all 4 elevations of plot 1-4, we have received only 3 elevations of plot 1-4

The submitted proposed sections do not have dimentions. Please provide  Proposed Sections of all new buildings with dimentions at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing the outline of the entire property not just part and showing dimensions.
Officers note that the vehicle tracking information submitted as part of this application has already been considered under planning application ref: 21/03821/KPSID.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed by relevant consultees and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 10 (Waste and Recycling Facilities), Condition 11 (Cycle Parking) and Condition 25 (Biodiversity provision) of planning permission 21/03821/KPSID which state:Condition 10 (Waste and Recycling Facilities) -Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of waste and recycling facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The refuse and recycling facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy SI17 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.Condition 11 (Cycle Parking) - Unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority, prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of secure cycle parking facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates, as set out below, shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Long Stay (Pupils - 76); (Staff - 22)Short Stay (Pupils - 6); (Staff - 0)Total (Pupils - 82); (Staff - 22)Cycle parking shall be in accordance with London Cycle Design Standards (LCDS) with at least 5% for larger and adapted cyclesThe cycle parking facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy T5 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.Condition 25 (Biodiversity provision) - Prior to commencement of above ground works, detailed plans of biodiversity provision, including a programme of works, shall be submitted to and approved by the Local Planning Authority before the relevant works are commenced. This shall include the types and location of boxes for bats and birds integrated into the built fabric; locations shown on appropriately scaled maps and plans; timetable for implementation, demonstrating that works are aligned with the proposed phasing of construction.The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved materials and maintained thereafter. Reason: To ensure no net loss of biodiversity and enhanced biodiversity

The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed by relevant consultees and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 5 (Boundary Treatment) Condition 10 (Cycle Parking), Condition 11 (Refuse and Recycle Facilities), Condition 14 (Day and Night Noise Level), Condition 15 (Noise Assessment), Condition 17 (Background Noise Level), and Condition 20 (Risk Assessment) of planning permission 22/00864/FUL which state:Condition 5 (Boundary Treatment) - Post demolition and prior to construction works, the following details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority, implemented prior to occupation and thereafter permanently retained:(a)  boundary treatment, including walls, fences and gates (including their manufacturer's specification, colour and texture).Reason: In order to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.Condition 10 (Cycle Parking)- The development hereby permitted shall not be occupied until details of secure cycle parking facilities for the occupants of, and visitors to, the development hereby approved have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.Condition 11 (Refuse and Recycle Facilities) - The development hereby permitted shall not be occupied until details of secure refuse and recycling facilities for the occupants of, and visitors to, the development hereby approved have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory refuse storage facilities and in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.Condition 14 (Day and Night Noise Level) - Prior to beneficial occupation of the development, a scheme shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority to demonstrate that the noise level of 35 dB LAeq,16 hour in living rooms and bedrooms during the daytime (0700 to 2300 hours) and 30 dB LAeq,8 hour during the night time (2300 to 0700 hours) in bedrooms, in accordance with BS8233:2014, shall not be exceeded. Noise levels in bedrooms should also not normally exceed 45 dB LAmax,F more than 10 times during the night time. Where these levels cannot be met with windows open appropriate acoustic ventilation should be provided so that the room can be sufficiently ventilated. The acoustic performance of any passive vent, variable speed mechanical air supply unit or whole house ventilation must be sufficient to ensure that the noise level standards given above are not compromised. Once agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority the approved details shall be installed prior to the development being occupied and retained thereafter.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D14 of the London Plan 2021 policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.Condition 15 (Noise Assessment) - Prior to beneficial occupation of the development the applicant shall provide to the Local Planning Authority an environmental noise assessment of noise levels affecting all external terraces and balconies.  Where noise levels exceed those recommended in BS8233:2014 a noise mitigation scheme shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for its written approval detailing measures to reduce those noise levels as far as reasonably practicable. Once agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority the approved details shall be installed prior to the development being occupied and retained thereafter.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D14 of the London Plan 2021 policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.Condition 17 (Background Noise Level) - Before the use hereby permitted commences an acoustic report shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority demonstrating that the rating level of any plant, permitted as part of this development, will be at least 5dBA lower than the existing background noise level at any given time of operation.  The noise levels shall be measured or predicted 1m externally to any window at the nearest residential facade.  Measurements and assessment shall be made according to British Standard 4142:2014.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D14 of the London Plan 2021 policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.Condition 20 (Risk Assessment) - Prior to the commencement of development an assessment of the risks posed by any contamination, carried out in accordance with British Standard BS10175: Investigation of potentially contaminated sites - Code of Practice and the Environment Agency's Model Procedures for the Management of Land Contamination (CLR 11) (or equivalent British Standard and Model Procedures if replaced), shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. Should an unacceptable risk be identified, no development shall commence until a report specifying the measures to be taken, including the timescale, to remediate the site to render it suitable for the approved development shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.The site shall be remediated in accordance with the approved measures and timescale and a verification report for all the remediation works shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure that risks from land contamination are minimised, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises an end of terrace dwelling located within the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character and 2.5 Coombe Hill Area of Archaeological Significance.The site is covered by a TPO group order.Proposal Erection of three storey side, single storey front and rear extension.Consultations15 properties were notified of the proposal.  Two representations have been received objecting to the proposal, with comments summarised as follows:- Effects on trees- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Inadequate landscaping/means of enclosure- Inappropriate design/layout- PrivacyOfficer comment: The above concerns will be addressed with this report. Relevant Planning History - 24/01418/PAEXT Erection of single storey rear extension (6m in depth, maximum height of 3m and eaves height of 2.9m) - prior approval not required 13.08.2024The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on the Heritage Assets; and,- The impact of the development on the protected trees; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Officers note concerns raised within the written representations regarding the proposed bulk and mass of the side extension.However, due to the proposed set back from the front elevation (approximately 0.9m), set down distance from the existing roof line, set in distance form the common boundary as well as the proposed width of the extension and design, it is considered that the proposed 3 storey side extension would appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition to the host dwelling and the surrounding area. Notwithstanding the submitted details of the materials, a relevant condition requesting further details of the proposed materials (colour, materiality/manufacturer details) would be added to ensure satisfactory appearance of the completion of development in an event of approval. The proposed front extension, due to its modest scale, siting and the proposed design is considered to be in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding properties.. The proposed single storey rear extension given the proposed depth of approximately 3m and height of approximately 2.6m is considered to appear as a subordinate addition to the host dwelling and the surrounding area. The proposed flat roof over this extension must not be used as a roof terrace/balcony, which would be secured via condition.Officers note the existing, protected trees adjoining the site boundaries. The protected trees  make a positive and valuable contribution to the quality of the public realm within Morecoombe Close and the character and appearance of the street and the wider area and in absence of any information demonstrating the impact of the proposal on the protected trees, it is considered that the potential loss of such trees as a result of the development would not be acceptable and would harm the overall character and appearance of the area. Officers note the recent planning history and the approved application ref no  24/01418/PAEXT for  Erection of single storey rear extension (6m in depth, maximum height of 3m and eaves height of 2.9m).The applicant is reminded that implementing this development in combination with another development, whether pursuant to permitted development rights, a prior approval or a planning permission could render the totality of the works unlawful. This is particularly the case where the proposals would physically adjoin. The applicant is strongly advised to seek further advice before proceeding with any approval.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers note concerns raised within the written representation regarding the potential loss of privacy and overbearing appearance as a result of the proposal. It is noted that there are no proposed openings in the side elevation of the proposal. Due to the siting of the proposal it is considered that it would not result in an unacceptable loss of privacy or an undue overlooking in relation to the adjoining property Holyoke.Given the mature trees along the common boundary with Holyoke and the separation distances and siting of the proposed side extension, it is considered that it would not appear as an overbearing when viewed from this adjoining property or Hertcombe, George Road.Given the separation distances to the adjoining property to the rear, Silverwoood House, the proposal is not considered to adversely affect the amenities of its occupiers. Due to the siting and modest scale of the proposed rear extension, it is considered not to adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers at the adjoining property No 6. The proposed flat roof area over the rear extension must not be used as a roof terrace, which would be secured via condition. Overall, it is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Protected TreesPolicy G7 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should ensure that, wherever possible, existing trees of value are retained. If planning permission is granted that necessitates the removal of trees, there should be adequate replacement. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 expects new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by Tree Preservation Orders (TPOs) are not adversely affected.The applicant has submitted a Tree Plan, however it does not capture all the protected trees that would be affected by the proposal, for example the existing trees along the common boundary with Holyoke which root protection zones are likely to be affected by the proposed 3 storey side extension. It is noted that the RBK's Trees Officer has raised objection to the proposal.As such, the applicant has failed to demonstrate through the submission of robust evidence that the proposal would not result in an unacceptable adverse impact upon the longevity, health and appearance of the protected trees which contribute towards the character and appearance of the surrounding area. Therefore, the proposed development would fail to preserve the character and appearance of the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character, contrary to Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012, Policy G7 of the London Plan 2021 and guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD 2013.ArchaeologyThe application site is situated within the Archaeological Priority Areas - Tier 2. According to the archaeological risk model provided by Greater London Archaeology Advisory Service, any householder developments situated within the Tier 2 Archaeological Priority Area are posing negligible risk, which means developments only rarely causing harm to heritage assets of archaeological interest and hardly ever causing significant harm.As such, due to the  scale of the proposal and its siting, it is considered that the proposed development would not result in significant harm to heritage assets of archaeological interest. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy and drawing FP01 Proposed Fire Plan, which are considered to be acceptable.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.
